title: Insights About the Thermal Decomposition of Violet Phosphorus Nanosheets from In Situ STEM
content: In the pursuit of optimized two-dimensional semiconducting materials, the layered phosphorus allotropes, black phosphorus and violet phosphorus, draw considerable attention due to their high carrier mobilities, tunable bandgaps, and strong prospects as functional materials [1-4]. In comparison to black phosphorus, violet phosphorus exhibits increased thermal stability, an important consideration for device design and implementation [5]. Thus, our inquiries here aim to examine the thermal behavior of violet phosphorus to better determine the structural transformations that lead to its ultimate decomposition at ∼400 °C. To accomplish this, we conducted three sets of complementary in situ scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) thermolysis experiments: (1) low kV in situ STEM to examine the morphological changes within violet phosphorus nanosheets, (2) detailed atomic-resolution structural analysis of observed morphologies using in situ aberration-corrected STEM, (3) evaluation of band structure dynamics using monochromated, aberration-corrected STEM and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS). The results of this highly effective analytical combination allowed us to develop a more comprehensive mechanism for the thermal breakdown of violet phosphorus nanosheets.
